textRegions.text: Git submodules
Tech talk
presented by
Greg Hurrell
Preliminaries
Git is the best version control system ever

Linus Torvalds
(creator of Git)
This is, of course, just an opinion
“CVS, Subversion, Perforce, Mercurial, Darcs... I’ve tried them all, but Git is the best.”
— Nicholas Cage, Academy Award Winner and Artistic Polymath
Although it is a widely-held one
Different opinions are respectfully welcomed
Just beware of angry mobs bearing torches

Git has an intimidating user interface

git-send-pack*git-clean*               git-merge-index*         git-sh-setupgit-clone*               git-merge-octopus*       git-shell*git-commit*              git-merge-one-file* git-unpack-objects*git-fast-import*         git-parse-remote         git-update-index*git-fetch*               git-patch-id*            git-update-ref*git-fetch-pack*          git-peek-remote*     git-web--browse*git-gc*                  git-rebase*              git-whatchanged*git-get-tar-commit-id*   git-rebase--interactive* git-write-tree*git-grep*                git-receive-pack*git-gui*                 git-reflog*
...but it has very simple internals
It’s not complex like a watch
It’s simple enough for anyone to understand
Git repository structure
Git repository structure
A Git repository consists of:
Git repository structure
A Git repository consists of:
a work tree: the checked-out files you’re currently working on
Git repository structure
A Git repository consists of:
a work tree: the checked-out files you’re currently working on
a “git dir”, containing the object database (repository history) and a bunch of meta information (branch names and so on)
Git repository structure
A Git repository consists of:
a work tree: the checked-out files you’re currently working on
a “git dir”, containing the object database (repository history) and a bunch of meta information (branch names and so on)
in a normal (non-bare) repo the “git dir” is a hidden directory called .git at the top level of the repo
The Git object model
The Git object model
4 types of objects:
The Git object model
4 types of objects:
Trees: a record of a directory tree in a particular state, change the tree, you change the identifying hash
The Git object model
4 types of objects:
Trees: a record of a directory tree in a particular state, change the tree, you change the identifying hash
Blobs: a snapshot of the contents of a file
The Git object model
4 types of objects:
Trees: a record of a directory tree in a particular state, change the tree, you change the identifying hash
Blobs: a snapshot of the contents of a file
Commits: attached to a particular tree, with meta-information about who committed and when, and parenthood
The Git object model
4 types of objects:
Trees: a record of a directory tree in a particular state, change the tree, you change the identifying hash
Blobs: a snapshot of the contents of a file
Commits: attached to a particular tree, with meta-information about who committed and when, and parenthood
Tags: optionally annotated, cryptographically-signed labels that can be attached to any object (usually used to tag commits)
Trees
Trees
Trees
Trees may reference other trees (subdirectories) and files and their contents (blobs)
Trees
Trees may reference other trees (subdirectories) and files and their contents (blobs)
They record basic permissions, filenames, and blobs (the content of each file)

SHA-1 hashes
SHA-1 hashes
hashes are used everywhere in Git to identify objects: trees, blobs and commits
SHA-1 hashes
hashes are used everywhere in Git to identify objects: trees, blobs and commits

if you change any aspect of a commit — either the contents in the tree, or the metadata in the commit message (including things like timestamps, parents, author, committer) — you’ll get a different hash
Commits with no parents

commit 4a55bb4d87ce040185a32e0c9138789039606c42tree 4b825dc642cb6eb9a060e54bf8d69288fbee4904author Tom Mornini <tmornini@causes.com> 1166664961 +0000committer Tom Mornini <tmornini@causes.com> 1166664961 +0000    Add basic repository structure            git-svn-id: http://svn/philotic/descolada/trunk@1 151021a3-42d0-4698-9f08-4a8d40defa4d
Commits with multiple parents
A “merge” commit is any commit with more than one parent

Directed Acyclic Graphs
commits form part of a Directed Acyclic Graph, or DAG
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Directed: because the relationship is recorded from child to parent
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Directed: because the relationship is recorded from child to parent
parent commits don’t “know” what children they have, if any
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Directed: because the relationship is recorded from child to parent
parent commits don’t “know” what children they have, if any
but each commit knows its parents
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Acyclic: because there can be no circular paths through the graph
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Acyclic: because there can be no circular paths through the graph
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Acyclic: because there can be no circular paths through the graph
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Acyclic: because there can be no circular paths through the graph
Directed Acyclic Graphs
Acyclic: because there can be no circular paths through the graph
Graphs have a “shape”, but the concepts of “space” and “position” are meaningless
Graphs have a “shape”, but the concepts of “space” and “position” are meaningless
Git only cares about parenthood
Graphs have a “shape”, but the concepts of “space” and “position” are meaningless
Git only cares about parenthood
That is, the topology of the graph, not the form it takes when you view it on the commandline with git log --graph, or with gitk, or on GitHub
The HEAD
The HEAD
The HEAD is a pointer to the currently checked out commit
The HEAD
The HEAD is a pointer to the currently checked out commit
It is recorded in .git/HEAD
$ cat .git/HEADref: refs/heads/master$ cat .git/refs/heads/master 20be4609587673a5de430c603af1d697be6bd3b4
Branches are just named HEADs
Branches are just named HEADs
examples of valid branch names:
Branches are just named HEADs
examples of valid branch names:
master
Branches are just named HEADs
examples of valid branch names:
master
greg/secret-topic-branch
Inspecting branches
using git branch -v

$ git branch -v  fabien-emailtracking 61239cf [behind 3] Not hard coding the encrypted anonymous_id  greg/gemfile-updates f3184b0 Move some test-time-only gems into the :test group  lady_gaga            f06a57e Merge branch 'lady_gaga'* master               b27a13b The causes_mailer gem is now a Git submodule
Inspecting branches
using git branch -v

$ git branch -v  fabien-emailtracking 61239cf [behind 3] Not hard coding the encrypted anonymous_id  greg/gemfile-updates f3184b0 Move some test-time-only gems into the :test group  lady_gaga            f06a57e Merge branch 'lady_gaga'* master               b27a13b The causes_mailer gem is now a Git submodule
Other ways of seeing branches
You can see branches under .git/refs/heads

$ ls -F .git/refs/headsfabien-emailtracking
greg/
lady_gaga
master
Other ways of seeing branches
You can see branches under .git/refs/heads

$ ls -F .git/refs/headsfabien-emailtracking
greg/
lady_gaga
master
Fast-forwarding and rewinding
Fast-forwarding
When somebody else does work on a branch while your HEAD remains stationary, you can “fast-forward” to incorporate their changes

your
old
HEAD

When somebody else does work on a branch while your HEAD remains stationary, you can “fast-forward” to incorporate their changes

your
old
HEAD

When somebody else does work on a branch while your HEAD remains stationary, you can “fast-forward” to incorporate their changes

your
old
HEAD
Rewinding A.K.A resetting
git reset effectively “rewinds” your HEAD by setting it to a prior position
Rewinding A.K.A resetting

current

previous
commit,
new HEAD after resetting

Rewinding A.K.A resetting

previous
commit,
new HEAD after resetting

current
HEAD
git reset effectively “rewinds” your HEAD by setting it to a prior position
technically, it can be used to move your head to any arbitrary commit, not just a prior one
git reset
git reset
git reset is just updating .git/HEAD to point at a new commit
git reset
git reset is just updating .git/HEAD to point at a new commit
it doesn’t even touch the work tree, unless you specify --hard
All the “fancy” stuff
All the “fancy” stuff
When you understand the underlying model of the object database and its DAGs, all the “fancy” stuff becomes simple
All the “fancy” stuff
When you understand the underlying model of the object database and its DAGs, all the “fancy” stuff becomes simple
branching, merging, topic branches, rebasing, git cherry-pick, git revert etc can all be understood in terms of simple operations on the DAG
The index
The index
The index
Sometimes referred to as “the staging area”
The index
Sometimes referred to as “the staging area”
An intermediate area
The index
Sometimes referred to as “the staging area”
An intermediate area
“Between” the work tree and the commit history
The index
Sometimes referred to as “the staging area”
An intermediate area
“Between” the work tree and the commit history
Used to prepare the tree that will form the basis of the next commit
The index
Sometimes referred to as “the staging area”
An intermediate area
“Between” the work tree and the commit history
Used to prepare the tree that will form the basis of the next commit
Managed by Git, but you can interact with it in various ways
Adding changes to the index (staging)
Adding changes to the index (staging)
Adding changes to the index:
Adding changes to the index (staging)
Adding changes to the index:
git add (stage an entire file or directory)
Adding changes to the index (staging)
Adding changes to the index:
git add (stage an entire file or directory)
git add --patch (stage changes hunk-by-hunk)
Reviewing the state of the index
Reviewing the state of the index
git diff (show changes in work tree, not yet committed or staged)
Reviewing the state of the index
git diff (show changes in work tree, not yet committed or staged)
git diff --cached (show staged changes)
Reviewing the state of the index
git diff (show changes in work tree, not yet committed or staged)
git diff --cached (show staged changes)
git diff HEAD (show both staged and unstaged changes, relative to HEAD)
Now, onto the meat of the talk
Git submodules
Submodules allow us to build complex
software out of modular components
Submodules
Submodules
Similar to Subversion externals
Submodules
Similar to Subversion externals
A way of incorporating an independent repo into another repo
Submodules
Similar to Subversion externals
A way of incorporating an independent repo into another repo
Terminology:
Submodules
Similar to Subversion externals
A way of incorporating an independent repo into another repo
Terminology:
The “submodule” is embedded inside the “superproject”
Differences from SVN externals
Differences from SVN externals
SVN externals track a path in another repo
Differences from SVN externals
SVN externals track a path in another repo
http://svn.example.org/foo-plugin/trunk
Differences from SVN externals
SVN externals track a path in another repo
http://svn.example.org/foo-plugin/trunk
This means that externals will automatically update to the latest contents at that path each time you update (unless you specifically peg them down with the -r switch)
Differences from SVN externals
SVN externals track a path in another repo
http://svn.example.org/foo-plugin/trunk
This means that externals will automatically update to the latest contents at that path each time you update (unless you specifically peg them down with the -r switch)
Git submodules on the other hand, are always tied to an explicit commit

Benefits of locking submodules to specific commits
Benefits of locking submodules to specific commits
Upstream projects won’t change “underneath you” when you’re not looking, possibly breaking your product
Benefits of locking submodules to specific commits
Upstream projects won’t change “underneath you” when you’re not looking, possibly breaking your product
Total control over the exact version of code you are running
Benefits of locking submodules to specific commits
Upstream projects won’t change “underneath you” when you’re not looking, possibly breaking your product
Total control over the exact version of code you are running
Guarantee that everyone who clones your repo is running the same version of code
Disadvantages of locking submodules to specific commits
Disadvantages of locking submodules to specific commits
Some overhead involved when updating
Disadvantages of locking submodules to specific commits
Some overhead involved when updating
must first update the submodule (via git pull, git checkout etc)
Disadvantages of locking submodules to specific commits
Some overhead involved when updating
must first update the submodule (via git pull, git checkout etc)
and then instruct the superproject to use the new commit (via git add and git commit)
Disadvantages of locking submodules to specific commits
Some overhead involved when updating
must first update the submodule (via git pull, git checkout etc)
and then instruct the superproject to use the new commit (via git add and git commit)
Learning curve required for people accustomed to other ways of sharing code
The tradeoff
The tradeoff
So, like all technology decisions there is a tradeoff involved
The tradeoff
So, like all technology decisions there is a tradeoff involved
For our workflow, I believe the benefits (robustness, control) outweigh the costs (overhead, learning)
Submodules were designed to handle massive codebases
Submodules were designed to handle massive codebases
in huge projects (millions of lines of code), you can check out a superproject and only check out the submodules when you explicitly need them
Submodules were designed to handle massive codebases
in huge projects (millions of lines of code), you can check out a superproject and only check out the submodules when you explicitly need them
this is why the first time you clone a superproject, you won’t end up cloning the submodules unless you explicitly make that happen (eg. git clone --recurse-submodules)
Submodules enable new workflows
Submodules enable new workflows
Because a submodule is a fully-fledged clone, you can do anything inside it that you would normally do in a Git repo:
Submodules enable new workflows
Because a submodule is a fully-fledged clone, you can do anything inside it that you would normally do in a Git repo:
work on new features, make commits, push and pull changes
Submodules enable new workflows
Because a submodule is a fully-fledged clone, you can do anything inside it that you would normally do in a Git repo:
work on new features, make commits, push and pull changes
test the new features out within the context of the superproject
Submodules enable new workflows
Because a submodule is a fully-fledged clone, you can do anything inside it that you would normally do in a Git repo:
work on new features, make commits, push and pull changes
test the new features out within the context of the superproject
when you’re done, update the superproject to use your new commit
Implementation
Implementation
3 components:
Implementation
3 components:
A “gitlink” in a tree
Implementation
3 components:
A “gitlink” in a tree
A .gitmodules file
Implementation
3 components:
A “gitlink” in a tree
A .gitmodules file
URLs configured in .git/config
A “gitlink” in a tree
A “gitlink” in a tree
a special entry in the tree object with “mode” 160000
A “gitlink” in a tree
a special entry in the tree object with “mode” 160000
instead of pointing at another tree (a subdirectory) or a blob (file contents), it points at a commit
A “gitlink” in a tree
a special entry in the tree object with “mode” 160000
instead of pointing at another tree (a subdirectory) or a blob (file contents), it points at a commit
the commit is identified by a SHA-1 hash that exists in the submodule repo, independently of the superproject
Gitlinks

$ git ls-tree HEAD vendor/plugins/040000 tree d76e73727f7031e275faae86dac70fd5b38d6b40	vendor/plugins/async_observer040000 tree 55904b26c4935b93dc8a5e3df14ec6c53a9eef5e	vendor/plugins/bookies160000 commit 6a8edb138e0c36b2e078b2be2218161f700d15ff	vendor/plugins/cacher160000 commit 1617efcd249917986a94551db2defc946ce68d79	vendor/plugins/css_browser_selector040000 tree 7d0e8777b4e5e99914e48a5c35632a9fc42b1041	vendor/plugins/gchartrb160000 commit b1d1b574525b025ecb6527887ad5d7be14cab144	vendor/plugins/lipsum040000 tree f8600df88bb723f2a67daae9c5a0ecfd1cf9592d	vendor/plugins/modesty160000 commit 40fdb5da12a360254df72b65ff865c266bce4fe0	vendor/plugins/mogli040000 tree 345e25c976c83985cd65ebcf6a44bb7f0f7827b6	vendor/plugins/newrelic_rpm160000 commit 81a3af890172f1280fe20a4806149b10ec024cd1	vendor/plugins/oops040000 tree d684ddc216f34d2a1377ea6f1ff2751011aed0f3	vendor/plugins/silence_health_logs040000 tree 761a19be4bd3c4380812715dd3bb467ff2f495c6	vendor/plugins/to_arid
The .gitmodules file

[submodule "vendor/plugins/oops"]	path = vendor/plugins/oops	url = git@github.com:causes/oops.git[submodule "vendor/gems/causes_mailer-0.1.8"]	path = vendor/gems/causes_mailer-0.1.8	url = git@github.com:causes/causes_mailer

URLs in .git/config
URLs in .git/config
it is possible to override the URLs defined in the .gitmodules file, using repository-local overrides in .git/config
URLs in .git/config
it is possible to override the URLs defined in the .gitmodules file, using repository-local overrides in .git/config
these custom overrides are not pushed when the repository is published
URLs in .git/config
it is possible to override the URLs defined in the .gitmodules file, using repository-local overrides in .git/config
these custom overrides are not pushed when the repository is published
this is great of open source projects, which can publish read-only URLs for their submodules, but whose developers can use read-write URLs while developing
Setting up .git/config entries
The initial entries in .git/config are set up when you do git submodule init (or git submodule update --init)

[submodule "vendor/plugins/cacher"]	url = git@github.com:causes/cacher.git[submodule "vendor/plugins/mogli"]	url = git://github.com/causes/mogli.git[submodule "vendor/plugins/oops"]	url = git@github.com:causes/oops.git
Setting up overrides
Overrides can be set up by manually editing .git/config, or using git config:

git config submodule.vendor/plugins/oops.url \
   git@github.com:causes/oops.git
Implications of implementation
Implications of implementation
git grep doesn’t recurse into submodules
Implications of implementation
git grep doesn’t recurse into submodules
git log -p -- some/submodule isn’t so interesting
Adding a new submodule

$ git submodule add git@github.com:/causes/shared_models.git vendor/plugins/shared_modelsCloning into vendor/plugins/shared_models...remote: Counting objects: 1654, done.remote: Compressing objects: 100% (807/807), done.remote: Total 1654 (delta 833), reused 1614 (delta 801)Receiving objects: 100% (1654/1654), 203.90 KiB, done.Resolving deltas: 100% (833/833), done.
Work tree and index state after adding a submodule

Pulling after a submodule has been added
Pulling after a submodule has been added
The next time somebody else pulls or clones the repo, they will receive the .gitmodules file and the corresponding gitlinks in their work tree
Pulling after a submodule has been added
The next time somebody else pulls or clones the repo, they will receive the .gitmodules file and the corresponding gitlinks in their work tree
At first the directory containing the submodule will be empty
Pulling after a submodule has been added
The next time somebody else pulls or clones the repo, they will receive the .gitmodules file and the corresponding gitlinks in their work tree
At first the directory containing the submodule will be empty
To populate it, we must run git submodule update --init
Converting a directory into a submodule
Converting a directory into a submodule
When a directory pre-exists in the worktree, we must first git rm -r it before performing the git submodule add
Converting a directory into a submodule
When a directory pre-exists in the worktree, we must first git rm -r it before performing the git submodule add
This may cause friction for other people moving back and forth between branches that contain and do not contain the conversion
Moving between branches with and without a submodule
Moving between branches with and without a submodule
Sometimes Git will complain when you try to switch branches or merge because of a submodule which exists on one branch where a directory exists on the other
Moving between branches with and without a submodule
Sometimes Git will complain when you try to switch branches or merge because of a submodule which exists on one branch where a directory exists on the other
It’s trying to prevent you from accidentally throwing away work
Moving between branches with and without a submodule
Sometimes Git will complain when you try to switch branches or merge because of a submodule which exists on one branch where a directory exists on the other
It’s trying to prevent you from accidentally throwing away work
If you don’t have any uncommitted changes in the affected directories, it is generally safe to rm -rf them, make your changes, and use git checkout later to restore any temporarily removed files
Workflow
Workflow
Submodules effectively “float” inside their superprojects
Workflow
Submodules effectively “float” inside their superprojects
As you commit/push/pull in the superproject, the submodules will stay where they were until you explicitly update them
Workflow
Submodules effectively “float” inside their superprojects
As you commit/push/pull in the superproject, the submodules will stay where they were until you explicitly update them
This is to avoid accidentally blowing stuff away
Following other peoples updates
Following other peoples updates
When somebody else updates the superproject to make a submodule point at a new commit, you’re submodule will continue to point at the old commit
Following other peoples updates
When somebody else updates the superproject to make a submodule point at a new commit, you’re submodule will continue to point at the old commit
If you don’t have any unsaved work inside the submodule, you can update it to point at the new commit with git submodule update

Seeing what changes you have in a submodule
git submodule summary
Seeing what changes you have in a submodule
git submodule summary

* vendor/plugins/oops 37108e4...0d25cbc (4):      > Rescue RuntimeError exceptions in the safe_log method      > Teach formatted_table to accept an optional width override      > Add formatted_table method      > Be more defensive about context object in the preamble method
git status output
git status will let you know when you have made changes in a submodule, but not yet updated the superproject to point to the new commits

# On branch master# Changes not staged for commit:#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)##       modified:   vendor/plugins/oops (new commits)
git status output
It will also let you know when you have uncommitted changes in a submodule

# On branch master# Changes not staged for commit:#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)#   (commit or discard the untracked or modified content in submodules)##       modified:   vendor/plugins/oops (modified content)
git status output
Likewise it will notify you of untracked content in the submodule

# On branch master# Changes not staged for commit:#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)#   (commit or discard the untracked or modified content in submodules)##       modified:   vendor/plugins/oops (untracked content)
git status output
When somebody else updates a submodule, until you do git submodule update, you’ll see

# On branch master# Changes not staged for commit:#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)#   (commit or discard the untracked or modified content in submodules)##       modified:   vendor/plugins/oops (new commits)
A potential pitfall
notice how commits you’ve made to a submodule and commits somebody else has made both result in the same “new commits” text in git status?

Differentiating between local and upstream updates

Differentiating between local and upstream updates
An earlier slide showed how git submodule summary will show local commits
You can see if upstream commits have been made with git submodule status (or just git submodule for short)
Interpreting git submodule status output
Interpreting git submodule status output
different prefixes mean different things:
Interpreting git submodule status output
different prefixes mean different things:
“-” means the submodule is not initialized (a git submodule init is required)
Interpreting git submodule status output
different prefixes mean different things:
“-” means the submodule is not initialized (a git submodule init is required)
“+” if the checked-out commit in the submodule does not match the commit recorded in the superproject
Interpreting git submodule status output
different prefixes mean different things:
“-” means the submodule is not initialized (a git submodule init is required)
“+” if the checked-out commit in the submodule does not match the commit recorded in the superproject
“U” if the submodule has merge conflicts
git submodule summary output
in addition, if there are upstream changes which you haven’t pulled in yet, you’ll see a message like:
Warn: vendor/plugins/oops doesn't contain commit 2239e5ba45b437e98a0f5e2c57d354425f04a016

you have to be cognizant of the two ways in which submodules can get updated (locally and upstream)

don’t ever blindly just git submodule update without thinking

you have to be cognizant of the two ways in which submodules can get updated (locally and upstream)

Consequences
you have to be cognizant of the two ways in which submodules can get updated (locally and upstream)
don’t ever blindly just git submodule update without thinking
instead, think about whether you want to:
git submodule update (the upstream changes will take effect, overriding your local changes)
git add and git commit your version of the submodule (your local changes will take effect, overriding the upstream changes)
Consequences
you have to be cognizant of the two ways in which submodules can get updated (locally and upstream)
don’t ever blindly just git submodule update without thinking
instead, think about whether you want to:
git submodule update (the upstream changes will take effect, overriding your local changes)
git add and git commit your version of the submodule (your local changes will take effect, overriding the upstream changes)
cd into the submodule and possibly merge your local changes with the upstream ones, committing the result to the superproject
And more generally
And more generally
be aware that the longer you work inside a submodule, the more likely someone else will commit during that period, requiring you to resolve this kind of conflict
And more generally
be aware that the longer you work inside a submodule, the more likely someone else will commit during that period, requiring you to resolve this kind of conflict
so commit early, commit often, publish your work in regular, incremental chunks, to minimize your exposure to a conflict
And more generally
be aware that the longer you work inside a submodule, the more likely someone else will commit during that period, requiring you to resolve this kind of conflict
so commit early, commit often, publish your work in regular, incremental chunks, to minimize your exposure to a conflict
consider whether your work is better done outside the submodule, in an independent clone of its repo

But be careful!
Submodule changes must be pushed before superproject changes
Submodule changes must be pushed before superproject changes
otherwise, you end up with a superproject that points to a submodule commit that hasn’t been published yet
Submodule changes must be pushed before superproject changes
otherwise, you end up with a superproject that points to a submodule commit that hasn’t been published yet
when others pull the superproject, they’ll be stuck with broken submodules

Why (some) of our deploys were broken over the weekend
Why (some) of our deploys were broken over the weekend
git submodule update --init does not mean “make all the submodules look like the superproject says they should”
Why (some) of our deploys were broken over the weekend
git submodule update --init does not mean “make all the submodules look like the superproject says they should”
it means “update the HEAD of each submodule to match the commit specified by the project”
Why (some) of our deploys were broken over the weekend
git submodule update --init does not mean “make all the submodules look like the superproject says they should”
it means “update the HEAD of each submodule to match the commit specified by the project”
if it is already has the right HEAD, it won’t touch the worktree
Why (some) of our deploys were broken over the weekend
git submodule update --init does not mean “make all the submodules look like the superproject says they should”
it means “update the HEAD of each submodule to match the commit specified by the project”
if it is already has the right HEAD, it won’t touch the worktree
this means that if you do something like delete all the files in a submodule, git submodule update --init won’t restore them

How to make git submodule update DWIMNWIS

How to make git submodule update DWIMNWIS
git submodule update will make sure the HEAD is pointing to the right commit

combine with git clean -f for 100% syncing

How to make git submodule update DWIMNWIS
git submodule update will make sure the HEAD is pointing to the right commit
git reset --hard HEAD in each submodule will undo any local changes there
combine with git clean -f for 100% syncing
shorthand for this:
git submodule foreach git reset --hard HEAD
git submodule foreach git clean -f
in recent versions of Git, you can specify --recursive too
Obviously, be careful with this kind of “shotgun” update

Not stomping on other people’s changes
Not stomping on other people’s changes
git add . and git commit -a are evil!
Not stomping on other people’s changes
git add . and git commit -a are evil!
with them, you may end up inadvertently reverting changes that somebody else has made to a submodule, by causing the superproject to point at a previous submodule commit
Bad habits
Bad habits
as a general rule of thumb, using git commit -a is like using a shotgun to kill flies; the risk of collateral damage is too great to justify their use on a regular basis
Bad habits
as a general rule of thumb, using git commit -a is like using a shotgun to kill flies; the risk of collateral damage is too great to justify their use on a regular basis
if you use git commit -a for anything but exceptional cases, you end up risking forming a very bad habit, in which you use it for everything
Good habits
Fortunately, Git has this incredibly useful index which you can get into the habit of using, and will lead you to making higher-quality commits, catching many bugs before they get committed

Who ever said that Obsessive Compulsive Disorders couldn’t be put to good use?
The OCD commit cycle:
git status (get high-level overview of changes)
git diff (detailed revision of changes)
git add --patch (stage changes hunk by hunk, reviewing them for sanity and correctness)
git diff --cached (review staged changes one more time)
git commit -v (review changes one last time, while committing)
git show (look at what you just committed)
git commit --amend (possibly reword or fix what you just committed)
Who ever said that Obsessive Compulsive Disorders couldn’t be put to good use?
The OCD commit cycle:
git status (get high-level overview of changes)
git diff (detailed revision of changes)
git add --patch (stage changes hunk by hunk, reviewing them for sanity and correctness)
git diff --cached (review staged changes one more time)
git commit -v (review changes one last time, while committing)
git show (look at what you just committed)
git commit --amend (possibly reword or fix what you just committed)
Now repeat (up to about 100 times per day)
Using Git aliases to support the formation of good habits

Another Pro-Tip™
Use colorization to be more aware of what’s going on in the repo
git config --global color.ui auto
Git hooks also help here
Our Git hooks will also warn you when you might potentially overwrite somebody else’s submodule changes, because they warn you about any commits under vendor (submodules usually live under vendor)

cpan App::Ack
or as a standalone script:

chmod 0755 ~/bin/ack
Getting Ack to work inside Vim
Probably multiple ways of doing this, but here is the recipe I’ve used:
Getting Ack to work inside Vim
Probably multiple ways of doing this, but here is the recipe I’ve used:

" in your .vimrcfunction! AckGrep(command)  cexpr system("ack " . a:command)  cw " show quickfix window alreadyendfunctioncommand! -nargs=+ -complete=file Ack call AckGrep(<q-args>)map <leader>a :Ack<space>
Getting Ack to work inside Vim
Probably multiple ways of doing this, but here is the recipe I’ve used:

" in your .vimrcfunction! AckGrep(command)  cexpr system("ack " . a:command)  cw " show quickfix window alreadyendfunctioncommand! -nargs=+ -complete=file Ack call AckGrep(<q-args>)map <leader>a :Ack<space>
Getting Ack to work inside Vim
Probably multiple ways of doing this, but here is the recipe I’ve used:

" in your .vimrcfunction! AckGrep(command)  cexpr system("ack " . a:command)  cw " show quickfix window alreadyendfunctioncommand! -nargs=+ -complete=file Ack call AckGrep(<q-args>)map <leader>a :Ack<space>

Closing tip
Closing tip
Submodules are still relatively “new” in the Git world (they were introduced in version 1.5.3)
Closing tip
Submodules are still relatively “new” in the Git world (they were introduced in version 1.5.3)
Git’s tools for working with submodules have been regularly improved since then
Closing tip
Submodules are still relatively “new” in the Git world (they were introduced in version 1.5.3)
Git’s tools for working with submodules have been regularly improved since then
So use a recent version of Git to make sure you have the best available tools
Updating Git
Updating Git
Git is very easy to update so there are no excuses
Updating Git
Git is very easy to update so there are no excuses
For example, to install the latest release (v1.7.5) in your home directory (no root privileges needed):
Installing a recent Git in your home directory
$ git clone git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/git/git.git$ cd git$ git checkout v1.7.5$ make prefix=~ test install quick-install-man
Installing a recent Git in your home directory
$ git clone git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/git/git.git$ cd git$ git checkout v1.7.5$ make prefix=~ test install quick-install-man
Installing a recent Git in your home directory
$ git clone git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/git/git.git$ cd git$ git checkout v1.7.5$ make prefix=~ test install quick-install-man
Installing a recent Git in your home directory
$ git clone git://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/git/git.git$ cd git$ git checkout v1.7.5$ make prefix=~ test install quick-install-man
Installing a recent Git system-wide

$ make test # or just “make” if you’re in a hurry
$ sudo make install quick-install-man
